Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Lhasa Block Top to Bottom-Lithospheric Evolution of Asia's Leading Edge
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Himalaya?Tibet orogenic system has been the subject of extensive research for decades, and continues to be a fruitful laboratory for understanding orogenic processes and continental evolution. Geological and geophysical studies have provided important insights into the structure and dynamics of the modern system, but imparted less information about the orogen?s early development, and the characteristics of the colliding continents that may affect subsequent evolution. The goal of this project is to investigate how crustal and lithospheric thickness changes in southern Tibet in order to establish the ?boundary conditions? for the India-Eurasia collision (~50 My ago) and how lithosphereic thickness changes during and after collision. As pointed out by the PIs, lithospheric thickness defines the thermal state and rheology of the crust and lithosphere, which are important boundary conditions and properties necessary for understanding the nature of crustal and lithospheric deformation during collision.

The PIs will integrate geochemistry, geochronology, paleoelevation, seismology, tectonics, and modeling to understand the pre-collision structure and evolution of the leading edge of the southern Asian continental margin ? the Lhasa block ? and its role in controlling the development of the broader orogen. They seek to answer two sets of related questions:

? How has the crustal thickness of the Lhasa block evolved from collision to the present?
? How have the elevation and denudation histories changed through time?
? What role does metamorphism play in altering crustal rheology and density and as a consequence facilitate surface uplift and erosion?
? What is the contribution of lithospheric deformation to thickening of the region?

This set of questions is relevant because of the way crustal thickness and surface elevation can influence the mechanics of an orogen.

The second set of related questions addresses the later evolution of the Lhasa block:

? What is the origin of post-collisional magmas?
? To what extent has melting contributed to crustal weakening and flow?
? How have magmatic and aqueous fluids and lateral heterogeneity in their distribution influenced evolution and deformation of the Lhasa block?
? Why are elevations in the Lhasa block relatively uniform despite considerable variations in geology, exhumation, and deep structure?

The importance of these questions derives from the control that rheology and its spatial
variations play in determining how orogens deform at large and small scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of our part of the project: Collaborative Research: Lhasa Block Top to Bottom-Lithospheric Evolution of Asia's Leading Edge was to provide an independent estimate of the crustal thickness of the Lhasa Block just prior to collision using stable isotope based paleoaltimetry and paleothermometry. Elevation and crustal thickness are well correlated through isostasy so knowing the paleoelevation should provide a clear estimate of crustal thickness. The focus of our fieldwork are sequences within and immediately south of the Lhasa Block containing materials suitable for stable isotope paleoaltimetry analyses.  Over the course of the lifespan of the grant we collected samples from a range of areas, including Penbo, Oiyug, Amu Xun, and Tsojiading. We examined other sections, including Machung and Mila Pass basin east of Maizhokunggar, but no suitable sequences were found in either of these localities. In addition, we analyzed previously collected materials and samples collected by collaborators.

Stable isotope-based paleothermometry or “clumped isotope thermometry or paleothermometry” estimates the formation temperature of carbonate precipitated from water. In close collaboration with Albert Colman and Gerry Olack at The University of Chicago graduate student Miquela Ingalls measured clumped isotope compositions and estimated paleo-temperatures for a wide range of samples related to this grant.  Stable isotope-based paleoaltimetry uses the difference D(d18Ow) derived from samples at potentially high elevation relative to the coeval near sea level samples as a proxy for paleo-elevation. Over the course of this grant several hundred measurements of d18Oc have been made on materials derived from our focus sites  as well as in collaboration with Li Shanying (Miami University) from the eastern Tibetan Plateau and adjacent lowlands, from the Lunpola and Hoh Xil Basins in collaboration with Xu Qiang (Institute for Tibetan Plateau Research, Chinese Academy of Sciences).

            The general outcomes of the current research can be summarized as follows.  Working with Li Shanying on the eastern margin of the Tibetan Plateau in Yunnan we determined the paleo-elevation history of several basins currently at elevations above 2800m.  The results, published in Li et al. (2015, EPSL, 432, p. 415-424) shows that the three studied basins along the eastern flank of the Tibetan Plateau were at approximately their current elevation by at least ~20 million years ago. Subsequent to our publication, a revision of the age of the Jianchuan Basin strata that we studied redated this sequence from ~20 Ma to ~35Ma implying that the eastern flank of the Tibetan Plateau’s topographic gradient is even older.  Currie et al. (2016) report a multi-proxy paleoaltimetry study of the Oiyug Basin in south-central Tibet. This study compares results from various carbonate phases including calcite, dolomite, and siderite, together with compound-specific dD. This study covers units that range from ~31Ma to ~5Ma in age. Here again the conclusion based on both d18O and dD indicate that this part of southern Tibet has been close to its current elevation since at least 31Ma.  More recent work in the Oiyug Basin adding clumped isotope and additional d18Oc measurements, extend this basin’s record back to ~55Ma. These new data recently submitted by Ingalls et al. (GSA Bulletin) indicate that high topography characterized this part of southern Tibet back to a time pre-dating collision.  In addition, this same manuscript reports results from the Penbo Basin, ~60 km north of Lhasa including both clumped and d18Oc measurements that are identical with those from Oiyug. 

             In collaboration with Xu Qiang we have new clumped isotope measurements from the Late Eocene to early Oligocene (~35 Ma) and Oligo-Miocene (~24 Ma) units of the Lunpola Basin. These measurements suggest quite cool (~9°C at 35 Ma and ~5°C at 24Ma) surface temperatures for both units, which together with depleted isotopic compositions are compatible with quite high paleo-elevations (>4km) for at least the past ~35 MY.

 

            One of the pressing questions related to the India-Asia collision relates to continental crustal mass balance. How much continental crust had to be there when collision began relative to how much we can account for today in the various crustal reservoirs. Ingalls et al. (2016- Nature Geosciences) provides the most detailed assessment of this problem and concludes that ~50% of the continental crust that was there at the beginning of collision ~56 Ma ago is no longer present in the current crustal reservoir of the Himalaya and Tibet, escaped crust of Indochina, or eroded sediments preserved in various sedimentary basins of southeast Asia. The implication of Ingalls et al. is that this eclogitized crust is continuously subducted into the mantle accounting for the crustal mass loss from this collision system. This has major implications for the geochemical evolution of the mantle in that direct subduction of crustal materials re-enriches the mantle, at least locally, and may account for various radiogenic isotope enriched mantle reservoirs seen in ocean island geochemistry.
